interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: 5 Broken Cameras
Review Date: 2013/10/16
Store: Emad Burnat  (Actor, Director),     Guy Davidi  (Director)    Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Featured Categories, DVD, Documentary
Product Description: ['Product Description', 'An extraordinary work of both cinematic and political activism, 5 Broken Cameras is a deeply personal, first-hand account of non-violent resistance in Bil\'in, a West Bank village threatened by encroaching Israeli settlements. Shot almost entirely by Palestinian farmer Emad Burnat, who bought his first camera in 2005 to record the birth of his youngest son, the footage was later turned into a galvanizing cinematic experience by co-directors Guy Davidi and Burnat. Structured around the violent destruction of a succession of Burnat\'s video cameras, the filmmakers\' collaboration follows one family\'s evolution over five years of village turmoil. Burnat watches from behind the lens as olive trees are bulldozed, protests intensify, and lives are lost. "I feel like the camera protects me," he says, "but it\'s an illusion".', 'Review', 'A rigorous and moving work of art. --A.O. Scott, The New York TimesUniquely powerful, putting faces and human consequences to a political dispute that will seemingly never end. --The Hollywood Reporter']
Average Rating: 4.5
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Special Interests', 'Format': 'Subtitled, Anamorphic, Multiple Formats, Dolby, Color, Surround Sound, Dubbed, NTSC, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Guy Davidi, Emad Burnat', 'Language': 'Hebrew', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 30 minutes', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': '26172163', 'Director': 'Emad Burnat, Guy Davidi', 'Media Format': 'Subtitled, Anamorphic, Multiple Formats, Dolby, Color, Surround Sound, Dubbed, NTSC, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 30 minutes', 'Release date': 'January 15, 2013', 'Actors': 'Emad Burnat', 'Dubbed': 'Arabic', 'Subtitles': 'English', 'Studio': 'Kino Lorber films', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: I think the issue of the Israeli occupation was a bit one sided from the biased point of view of the Palastinians. I suppose it could have gone both ways.
Review Title: My opinion
Rating: 4.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
5 Broken Cameras
Emad Burnat  (Actor, Director),     Guy Davidi  (Director)    Rated:    NR    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Featured Categories, DVD, Documentary
['Product Description', 'An extraordinary work of both cinematic and political activism, 5 Broken Cameras is a deeply personal, first-hand account of non-violent resistance in Bil\'in, a West Bank village threatened by encroaching Israeli settlements. Shot almost entirely by Palestinian farmer Emad Burnat, who bought his first camera in 2005 to record the birth of his youngest son, the footage was later turned into a galvanizing cinematic experience by co-directors Guy Davidi and Burnat. Structured around the violent destruction of a succession of Burnat\'s video cameras, the filmmakers\' collaboration follows one family\'s evolution over five years of village turmoil. Burnat watches from behind the lens as olive trees are bulldozed, protests intensify, and lives are lost. "I feel like the camera protects me," he says, "but it\'s an illusion".', 'Review', 'A rigorous and moving work of art. --A.O. Scott, The New York TimesUniquely powerful, putting faces and human consequences to a political dispute that will seemingly never end. --The Hollywood Reporter']

profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

The user demonstrates a keen interest in documentary films, particularly those exploring political and social issues. They are drawn to works that present personal narratives and firsthand accounts, indicating a preference for deep, genuine storytelling. The user appreciates cinematic activism and seems to value films that address complex global conflicts, particularly those related to the Israeli-Palestinian situation.

Their rating suggests a favorable view of the documentary format, though they exhibit a critical perspective regarding bias, as seen in their reflection on the one-sided nature of the film's portrayal of the Israeli occupation. This indicates that the user prefers a balanced exploration of viewpoints in political narratives.

Overall, the user favors thought-provoking content that challenges perceptions and encourages introspection about contemporary issues, reflecting an engaged and analytical outlook on media.
